title: Planning to Perceive: Exploiting Mobility for Robust Object Detection

author: Javier Velez, Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT

As a robot, this is going to allow us to process some higher level queries such as go clean underneath the couch.
That's something we can do if we know where the couches.

So the question is, can we do better than just slapping on the object detector and running our algorithm is normal.
In fact, can we plan trajectories through the world that are going to improve our object detection in order to get better semantic Maps at the end?

So the question is what trajectory we're going to take from where we are to the goal that's going to allow us to both get to the goal location and accurately detect this object adventures and place it on our map.
There's a couple approaches already in literature for this.
The first one I'm going to call the shortest path approach.
You simply go to the goal in the shortest path an you continuously run your object detector.
You accept the object based solely upon the detector, then whether it's detecting the object or not, this is a great approach because it's fast.
You get to the goal in the shortest path possible.
Unfortunately, you don't really know the quality detection you're going to get at the end because you basically always took the shortest path, regardless of where the object.
Was potentially where it was.
The other approach is what I call the information gathering approach.
Here you have a threshold on the belief you want over the object being there or not, and then you go and gather as much information as you want about the object.
This is basically going around and taking detections from around the object.
Once you're satisfied that you know whether the object is there or not, you then go to the goal.
It's great if you really want to know whether the object is there or not.
However, you really don't know what the path length will be at the end of this algorithm.
It doesn't take that into consideration.

So what we're going to do is we're actually going to mix these two together and say that the cost for going and taking an observation is going to be the information gained, so there's going to be some good thing there because you're going to get information about the object.
